Cooperative advocators and capitalist haters alike will buy intoxicants

will tip the waiters with a celerity
which was never noted when they

Dr Chalmers, who was the third
speaker in the supper series, stated
that his reasons for believing that
man could get exist without religion
was based on the "good proof" that
"men are doing it now."
When asked what he thought
would be the sensation one would experience when meeting religion for
the first time. Dr Chalmers replied
that the individual would be "instilled with a haunting desire to fight
against injustice, dishonesty and
other evils."
The speaker is a prominent member of the peace movement and chairman of the Scotsboro defense committee. The latter group has succeeded in freeing four of the negroes involved in the case and is now working to free the remaining five.
In 1937 he was a delegate to the
Conference on Church, Community
and State in Oxford, England. He is
also a member of the War Registers'
League, National Association for the
advancement of colored people, Federal council of Christian churches
and Interracial Committee of the
YWCA and the YMCA.
iDr Chalmers also spoke later at
the Lectu-re series. He chose to discuss religion of the modern world
under the topic "Candles in the wind."
lOn January 10 the Supper Club
and Lecture Series will hear Mark
Starr, Education director of the International ladies' garment workers' union. Mr Starr is a charter
member of the National Council of
Labor colleges. Since coming to this
country ten years ago, he has served
on the staffs of the Brookwood Labor
college and the Bryn Mawr summer
school. Mr Starr is also a member
of the American federation of teachers, executive board of the affiliated
schools for workers, the League for
industrial democracy, and the New
York adult education council.

At the intermission., T W McElhiney, master of ceremonies, introduced the charming co-sponsors of
the dance to the crowd, and Mel
Spraggins awarded a big, juicy box
of chocolates to Jack Williams who
held the lucky number 16.
The climax of the evening came
when Maestro Craig played his foxtrot arrangement of none other than
"Dear Old Johnny Hopkins" and was
joined by an enthuisiastic chorus of
students and their dates. The "Victory
March", arranged into a dance tune
by Craig and led by George L Miller
and his sweet baritone voice, folowed.
The chorus broke up into couples
and took to the dance.
The arrangement of "Dear Old
Johnny Hopkins" by Craig has been
played over the radio by Horace
Heidt recently, and will be played
shortly by Enoch Light over his radio
program.

HOMEWOOD,

Hoopsters
whip into
shape
Enthusiastic over the turn out of
two fine freshmen prospects, Bud
Tannenbaum and Sammy Lucido,
Coach Gardner Mallonee has been
charges
basketball
his
sending
through daily drills in order to have
them ready for their opening joust
with Gallaudet on December 16.
Tannenbaum, All-Maryland selection during his last two years at
City College, seems a certainty to
break into the starting line up. However, he is a team man and is not
the type of player who will run up
new highs in scoring. Another newcomer, Lucido, has been displaying
unusual prowess on the court and will
probably see plenty of action during
the course of the season. In addition,
Melvin, Cross, and Moore have returned from last year's team and
should add balance to the quintet.
Melvin, a standout on last year's outfit, gives appearance of being even
better this season.
Other men out for basketball who
have exhibited more than passing
ability are Terpenning, Van Horn Wagner, Robinson, Remsen, and Sullivan,
the last two named playing freshman ball last year.
At the last practice, the squad
was cut. and those retained will probably form the nucleus of the team.
However, Coach Mallonee made it
clear that the present group was not
definite and indicated that changes
would be made from time to time.
Nine players compose the present
varsity.
All factors point to a banner year
for the Hopkins basketeers. Although
last year's group compiled a fair
record in winning eight of their sixteen games, the present team with
such an abundance of excellent material on hand should have little difficulty emerging victor in more than
half of its skirmishes. Incidentally,
Coach Mallonee is working on some
new plays with his charges and
promises to have a few surprises for
Gallaudet when the season starts.

Wrestlers start
mat practice

The

The Hopkins gymnasium is a beehive of activity on these wintry afternoons. One corner of the floor is occupied by a group of youngsters,
thirty-seven in all, who are competing for positions on the wrestling
team.
Coach Baer has only one dyed-inthe-wool veteran, Captain Edwards,
who has been wrestling for the last
three years. The other four lettermen have had only one year's experience with the exception of Corse,
who groaned and grunted for his high
school. Practically all positions are
wide open, and there is a chance for
anyone who will just come up to the
gym on week-day afternoons and tryout for the team. The grapplers lost
two good men last year when King
and Vernon both left school. Some of
the newcomers have to fill in the vacancies.
Coach Baer has devoted some time
to skull practice, explaining to the
new men that there is more to wrestling than simple brute strength. The
tryouts are being drilled in the fundamentals and they are slowly getting into good physical condition.
Coach Baer has plenty of time to get
his grapplers into shape, as the first
meet doesn't take place until Janu-

for championship
Epsilon Tau Alpha came from behind Wednesday to nose out an inspired Kappa Sig team, 20-18, to
clinch the league A football championship for the second consecutive
season. ETA clashes with Pi Lam,
winner of league B, this afternoon
at the gym for the 1938 interfraternity football championship. The game

will start at 4 o'clock.

kick and ETA led 8-6.

Indians put away clubs
as fall lacrosse practice ends
Fall lacrosse practice came to an
end last Friday. The Indians have decided to cease practicing their prewar activities and lay aside their
hatchets.
The weather which has been very
good for lacrosse has given Coach
Kelso Morrill and "Father Bill"
Schmeisser ample opportunity to look
over their charges for the coming
season. The prospects this year are
very encouraging.
The veteran attack, which in itself is very good, has been considerably improved by the addition of a
fine freshman turn out plus several
returning junior varsity men.
The defense at present is not as
encouraging. There are only a few
veterans returning from last year's
squad, and there is little freshmen talent on the defense side of the game.
Outstanding junior varsity talent
is well represented in Sydney Checkett, attack, Louis Rostov, defense,
Bob Fleagle, center.
Harry Nance, Samuel J Lucido,
jr, on the attack, Arthur LeRoy
Swerdloff, goal; Don Wilson and Bill
Wood on the defense demonstrated
exceptional skill.
The primary purpose of these practices has been to have the new talent

The Senior Engineers downed the
Sophomore Business quintet in the
other contest, 18-13. The Sophs took
the lead when Rubin sank a foul
shot, then Day tied the score several
seconds later in the same manner.
Goalsby, Zavertnik and Day gave the
Seniors a 5 to 1 lead before O'Neill
counted for the Weyforth men. Both
teams scored as the half ended with
the Engineers leading 8 to 5.
The Engineers ran the score to
14-5 at the beginning of the second
half, before the Sophs put on a spurt
which made the score 14 to 13. The
Businessmen's attack stalled at this
point and the Engineers scored twice
before the game ended. The final
score was Senior Engineers 18,
Sophomore Business 13.
Day and Zaverinik starred for the
Seniors while Hazand and O'Neill
played well for the Sophs.

quarter plan. (Four quarters of eleven weeks each, to the school year).

Alpha Chi Rho
initiates
Alpha Chi Rho held an initiation
of postulants on Sunday, Dec 4th.
Seven new men were formally accepted by the fraternity at that time.
They were:
John Ford, '42; Joseph Alsop, '39;
Pearce Davenport, '42; Edward
French, Jr, '40; Gordon Holland, '42;
Robert Gruver, '42, and Armin Jaeger, III, '42.
Edward Owens, '41, and Gordon
Cummings, '41 were granted extended pledges.
. Following the initiation a dinner
was held at the Longfellow. It was
attended by the alumni and distingmembers of the fraternity
colleges, among whom
other
from
were William H D Cox, National
President, and Wilbur M Walden,
uished

Executive Secretary. The University
was represented by Prof Donald
Hatch Andrews, an alumnus of Al-

"Barnstormers' and the Interfraternity board. Day is president of the
Athletic council.
Then Robert Kimball, president of
the Alpha chapter of Tau Beta Pi,
national honorary engineering fraternity, presented a slide rule to Joseph
Cumming of the class of '41 for attaining the highest average in his
class as a freshman. He then announced that Frederic Whelan, Malcolm Ogle, Charles Rothage, John
Snodgrass, John Wetzler, and William Day had been elected to Tau
Beta Pi.
Then Harold Ricards, president of
the student council, introduced Turner Catledge. At present Mr Catledge is with the New York Times,
although he was formerly a reporter
on the Baltimore Sun. He spoke on
the news from a reporter's angle. He
told about the reactions of the different presidents to reporters and
press conferences. He discussed the
conditions a reporter was obliged
to cope with during the various administrations from President 'Taft's
down to the present. Included in this
discussion were interesting accounts
of the press policies and idiosyncrasies of the different presidents.

laughed, "Oh, what fun!"
The friendly informal attitude of
Nance and Miller seemed to be
typical of the whole affair. The affair
was presented in cabaret style.

by A. LEROY SWERDLOFF
When a dog bites a man or when a
debutante comes to Dr. Mitchell's
class it's news.
'Twas the morning after the
Batchelor's cotillon and all over the
Hopkins campus there was serenity
till two debutantes visited Dr
Mitchell's 9:30 class in economics. It
was such good news that every seat
was occupied.
The bell rang, the noise faded to a
murmur, and then Dr Mitchell spoke:
"I don't know what brought this
on, but I am delighted to have such
responsive talent this morning. We
have been studying the primary
causes of the industrial revolution
and since you have such eagerness to
learn, you shall certainly get the opportunity."
The visiting students held their
breath, then Dr Mitchell continued:
"The inequality of wealth distribution has frequently been condemned. It is estimated that one
family out of every 400 on the average has as much income as the other
399 put together."
"It would cost approximately $13
a week for a family of four to be put
on direct relief. Let us bear this point
in mind, for we will return to it.
"Now, just what did this cotillion
cost?" The Students gave a sigh of
relief. Dr Mitchell got up, prepared
to write on the board. He inquired
how many people attended the dance.
The number given by one of the students in the class, was 1,147 people,
75 debutantes. In round numbers
there were 800 men and 400 women
present. He then proceeded to obtain
a list of the items for this dance, with
estimated cost of each.
In the calculating of the cost of
certain garments which might be
worn more than once, only a part of
the cost was allocated to this dance.
The debutantes were at variance
upon the price of food. The one said
$1.25 a plate while the other maintained $.50. Dr Mitchell looked over
to the one and said:
"If it was just a snack? The young
lady said she had a sandwich."
"I didn't say that" she replied.
Finally the debutantes compromised
and the price was set at $1.00 a plate,
a total of $1200.
They disagreed again about the
price of boxes of flowers. One said
$5 the other $3, whereupon Dr
Mitchell explained the difference was
between the liberal and conservative.
The liquor queStion was reached.
The students agreed that 600 pints
would be a fair figure.
"Oh, no, not that much liquor!"
one of the debutantes answered,
"They had mostly White Rock, carbonated water."

"What

about

the

champagne?"

some one remarked.
"Oh

the

champagne

didn't last

very long" she retorted.
When Dr Mitchell was questioning the girls- about the cost of various pieces of women's clothing and
incidentals used at the dance there
would

infrequently

be

disturbing

murmurs about how low some of the
prices were set. Dr Mitchell invariably had to stop to tell them.
"Now wait a minute, you don't
know anything about women's dresses."
"There are a lot of things which
show up very well but really didn't
cost much." commented a debutante.
"Indeed," Dr Mitchell added, "I've
heard that at some hunting clubs you
could get a good deal of second hand
things: you could get a second hand
saddle, a second hand pair of boots
and even a second hand fox." •
"What about the railroad fare?"
questioned a student. Wouldn't those
people coming from New York have
to pay a fare?
"That is a good point" affirmed Dr
Mitchell, "a lot of these people are
from foreign countries like---Catonsville.
The following list is the approximate value of the terns which were
determined. "It is by no means an
exact list" said Dr Mitchell.
$400 for rental, $1200 food, $1000
orchestra, $50 decorations, $1000
corsages, $24,000 flowers, $100 parties, $600 liquor, $2400 railroad, $600
tax, $3200 dresses, $200 shoes, $160
stockings, $800 undies, $200 wraps,
$700 hairaressers, $125 manicures,
$800 men's suits, $2000 vests, shirts,
ties, etc., $2000 jewelry, $200 men's
coats, hats, $200 women's gloves,
$2500 invitations and cards, $800 tips
and $1500 for hotels. Total—$49,430
or approximately $650 per debutante
was spent.
When we return to the original
statement that $13 would support
a family of four people on relief for
one week, we discover that 50 families
for one week could be supported by
the money spent on each debutante.
Or a relief population (two families
to the house) filling the area between
Charles street to Harford road and
North avenue to 32nd street, could be
supported for one week.
The point of the lecture is whether
it is advantageous to stimulate such
business since many people might
say that the florists and hairdressers
etc., had to be kept alive, while people
in the society are starving for food.
At this point the bell rang ending
this delightful period.

J B Lawrence

in this corner
I write this paragraph on Dec 4;
it may or may not be published before Christmas, regardless of the sympathy and wishes of the editor and,
I am led to believe, a majority of the
N-L board. Not yet this school year
has this column appeared within two
weeks of submission. Twice it has
been mysteriously lost in the N-L
office where the forces of liberalism
make their terrestrial home. Because
of the state of anarchy existing
among the editorial staff, two or
three obstructionist underlings, cringing in fear of an outbreak of independent thought have resorted to
surreptitious sabotage, and even to
oiirright, brazen suppression. They
have created a real need for the
school motto; but campus opinion
cannot be made free, if truth itself
is gagged and fettered. This paper
has ceased to represent a cross-section of campus opinion; instead, a
minority of malcontents has corrupted the ideals of journalism by their
petty totalitarianism.
THREE out of four fighters for
pure principle who sat on the platform at the the-dean-is-unwise-butwe-love-him meeting are members of
the ASU. The demonstration was informed that the speakers represented a certain "Committee of Thirty."
I do not believe that the ASU has a
large enough membership to fill threefourths quota on such a committee,
but it may be assumed that they did
the best they could. Must we accept
such a percentage as representative
of the campus, and if not, where is all
their beloved democracy, whose name
they take in vain? Note that practically all the revolutions in history
were formented by self-seeking minorities who duped the masses with
tempting catchwords of idealism.
Then as now, these self-appointed
popular leaders represented no one
but themselves and their personal interests.
The face of the N-L was badly

blackened by a recent headline therein Hearstly referred to the "Jap
Policy." This is disgraceful and inexcusable. Brevity cannot be used as
an explanation; if such an argument
is admissable, why not go the whole
hog? Will there be headlines of Frogs
Chinks, Wops, Hunks, Boches, or
Limeys?
THE PRESIDE= in his pre-election indorsement of Murphy of Michigan seemed to smear himself with
Chamberlainism. He praised Murphy
for yielding to force and thereby
avoiding violence. In the Flint affair,
Murphy, because of his sympathies
with the aims of the strikers, surrendered to his fear -and refused to
allow his law-enforcement agencies
to function. There is in Michigan,
as in England, a need for courageous
public officials which is greater than
the supply.
FIGHT DISEASE! "World Healthways, Inc" has the plan by which
suffering humanity will be spared the
total economic waste of doctor's bills,
and at the same time can eliminate
from the face of the earth those merchants of death, the medical profession, who collect profits from the sick
and dying, and are doubtless secretly
involved in the spreading of epidemics. Let us liberals rid the world of
these monsters, and their tool and
means of livelihood—disease, which
menace us all; nor does it discriminate in favor of women or babies, but
71aughters without scruple for age or
sex. What is our plan? We will assemble representatives from all over
the country and through them, all
will swear a holy oath that disease
must cease, and that no more of our
hard-earned salaries will be paid to
heartless, undemocratic, greedy science. America needs schools, not hospitals. Too long our hapless land has
yielded power and plunder to the
aristocratic medical clique. Idealism
must rise and conquer; join now!

HOMEWOOD,

Hoopsters
whip into
shape
Enthusiastic over the turn out of
two fine freshmen prospects, Bud
Tannenbaum and Sammy Lucido,
Coach Gardner Mallonee has been
charges
basketball
his
sending
through daily drills in order to have
them ready for their opening joust
with Gallaudet on December 16.
Tannenbaum, All-Maryland selection during his last two years at
City College, seems a certainty to
break into the starting line up. However, he is a team man and is not
the type of player who will run up
new highs in scoring. Another newcomer, Lucido, has been displaying
unusual prowess on the court and will
probably see plenty of action during
the course of the season. In addition,
Melvin, Cross, and Moore have returned from last year's team and
should add balance to the quintet.
Melvin, a standout on last year's outfit, gives appearance of being even
better this season.
Other men out for basketball who
have exhibited more than passing
ability are Terpenning, Van Horn Wagner, Robinson, Remsen, and Sullivan,
the last two named playing freshman ball last year.
At the last practice, the squad
was cut. and those retained will probably form the nucleus of the team.
However, Coach Mallonee made it
clear that the present group was not
definite and indicated that changes
would be made from time to time.
Nine players compose the present
varsity.
All factors point to a banner year
for the Hopkins basketeers. Although
last year's group compiled a fair
record in winning eight of their sixteen games, the present team with
such an abundance of excellent material on hand should have little difficulty emerging victor in more than
half of its skirmishes. Incidentally,
Coach Mallonee is working on some
new plays with his charges and
promises to have a few surprises for
Gallaudet when the season starts.

Wrestlers start
mat practice

The

The Hopkins gymnasium is a beehive of activity on these wintry afternoons. One corner of the floor is occupied by a group of youngsters,
thirty-seven in all, who are competing for positions on the wrestling
team.
Coach Baer has only one dyed-inthe-wool veteran, Captain Edwards,
who has been wrestling for the last
three years. The other four lettermen have had only one year's experience with the exception of Corse,
who groaned and grunted for his high
school. Practically all positions are
wide open, and there is a chance for
anyone who will just come up to the
gym on week-day afternoons and tryout for the team. The grapplers lost
two good men last year when King
and Vernon both left school. Some of
the newcomers have to fill in the vacancies.
Coach Baer has devoted some time
to skull practice, explaining to the
new men that there is more to wrestling than simple brute strength. The
tryouts are being drilled in the fundamentals and they are slowly getting into good physical condition.
Coach Baer has plenty of time to get
his grapplers into shape, as the first
meet doesn't take place until Janu-

Meets Pi Lam Wednesday
for championship
Epsilon Tau Alpha came from behind Wednesday to nose out an inspired Kappa Sig team, 20-18, to
clinch the league A football championship for the second consecutive
season. ETA clashes with Pi Lam,
winner of league B, this afternoon
at the gym for the 1938 interfraternity football championship. The game

will start at 4 o'clock.
- ETA won the toss and chose to
receive the opening kickoff. Hazard
booted the ball to Rosett who ran
the ball back five yards to the ETA
twenty-five. On the first play a short
pass by Milberg intended for Checkett was intercepted by Billovits and
the Kappa Sigs were on the midfield stripe. After four tries had •failed to gain more than seven yards,
.Billovits dropped back and threw a
beautiful thirty yard pass to Hazard
who had gotten behind the ETA secondary and the score was Kappa Sig
6, ETA 0.
Hazard got off a poor kick and
ETA took the ball at midfield. On
the first play Milberg tossed to
Checkett over the goal to knot the
score at 6-6.
Milberg kicked off to Billovits on
his one yard line. On the first play
Miller dropped back to kick but Tannenbaum broke through to block the
kick and ETA led 8-6.

Bob Hoopes, soccer and trackman,
is managing the grunters this year.
The '38 record wasn't too impressive
with the Jays winning one meet while
losing five. This year's schedule is
identical with that of '38 except for
one change. The Jay grapplers will
meet Rutgers instead of Lafayette
this year. The balance of the schedule includes two matches with Maryland, and one each with Haverford,

Indians put away clubs
as fall lacrosse practice ends
Fall lacrosse practice came to an
end last Friday. The Indians have decided to cease practicing their prewar activities and lay aside their
hatchets.
The weather which has been very
good for lacrosse has given Coach
Kelso Morrill and "Father Bill"
Schmeisser ample opportunity to look
over their charges for the coming
season. The prospects this year are
very encouraging.
The veteran attack, which in itself is very good, has been considerably improved by the addition of a
fine freshman turn out plus several
returning junior varsity men.
The defense at present is not as
encouraging. There are only a few
veterans returning from last year's
squad, and there is little freshmen talent on the defense side of the game.
Outstanding junior varsity talent
is well represented in Sydney Checkett, attack, Louis Rostov, defense,
Bob Fleagle, center.
Harry Nance, Samuel J Lucido,
jr, on the attack, Arthur LeRoy
Swerdloff, goal; Don Wilson and Bill
Wood on the defense demonstrated
exceptional skill.

The Senior Engineers downed the
Sophomore Business quintet in the
other contest, 18-13. The Sophs took
the lead when Rubin sank a foul
shot, then Day tied the score several
seconds later in the same manner.
Goalsby, Zavertnik and Day gave the
Seniors a 5 to 1 lead before O'Neill
counted for the Weyforth men. Both
teams scored as the half ended with
the Engineers leading 8 to 5.
The Engineers ran the score to
14-5 at the beginning of the second
half, before the Sophs put on a spurt
which made the score 14 to 13. The
Businessmen's attack stalled at this
point and the Engineers scored twice
before the game ended. The final
score was Senior Engineers 18,
Sophomore Business 13.
Day and Zaverinik starred for the
Seniors while Hazand and O'Neill
played well for the Sophs.
The Wednesday basketball league
got off to a good start this week
with four teams seeing action.
In the first game, the Literaries
continued their usual winning stride
by defeating a good A S U team, 2412. The Literati, despite the fact
that they are missing several members of their team, due to their varsity potentiality, took the lead when
Bernstein sank a drib shot, and the
outcome was never in doubt.
,Silverstein rang up two points for
the Literati before Kaufman scored
the first A S U basket. With Bernstein, Koenig, and Silverstein scoring the Literati pulled away to a
15 to 7 lead at the half.
The Literati were content to pro
tect their lead during the second
half and neither team did much
scoring. The final score was Literati
24, A S U 12. Bernstein starred for
the Literati while Kaufman played
well for A S U.

Alpha Chi Rho
initiates
Alpha Chi Rho held an initiation
of postulants on Sunday, Dec 4th.
Seven new men were formally accepted by the fraternity at that time.
They were:
John Ford, '42; Joseph Alsop, '39;
Pearce Davenport, '42; Edward
French, Jr, '40; Gordon Holland, '42;
Robert Gruver, '42, and Armin Jaeger, III, '42.
Edward Owens, '41, and Gordon
Cummings, '41 were granted extended pledges.
. Following the initiation a dinner
was held at the Longfellow. It was
attended by the alumni and distingmembers of the fraternity
colleges, among whom
other
from
were William H D Cox, National
President, and Wilbur M Walden,
uished

Executive Secretary. The University
was represented by Prof Donald
Hatch Andrews, an alumnus of Al-

"Barnstormers' and the Interfraternity board. Day is president of the
Athletic council.
Then Robert Kimball, president of
the Alpha chapter of Tau Beta Pi,
national honorary engineering fraternity, presented a slide rule to Joseph
Cumming of the class of '41 for attaining the highest average in his
class as a freshman. He then announced that Frederic Whelan, Malcolm Ogle, Charles Rothage, John
Snodgrass, John Wetzler, and William Day had been elected to Tau
Beta Pi.
Then Harold Ricards, president of
the student council, introduced Turner Catledge. At present Mr Catledge is with the New York Times,
although he was formerly a reporter
on the Baltimore Sun. He spoke on
the news from a reporter's angle. He
told about the reactions of the different presidents to reporters and
press conferences. He discussed the
conditions a reporter was obliged
to cope with during the various administrations from President 'Taft's
down to the present. Included in this
discussion were interesting accounts
of the press policies and idiosyncrasies of the different presidents.

new swing ditties as well as his new

Even some of the tin-eared ickies

Comments
"Tell the freshmen and sophs
thanks for supporting the dance,"
smiled George L Miller carrying a
cocktail in either hand and appearing entirely satisfied with everything.
"We might not have made a mint
of money," crated Harry Nance in
true Ciceronian fashion, "but because
of the support of the student to
their class and because of the fine
show of spirit at the dance", he broke
off here, hesitated, wet his finger
wth his tongue, and pressed it into
the palm of his other hand and
laughed, "Oh, what fun!"
The friendly informal attitude of
Nance and Miller seemed to be
typical of the whole affair. The affair
was presented in cabaret style.

by A. LEROY SWERDLOFF
When a dog bites a man or when a
debutante comes to Dr. Mitchell's
class it's news.
'Twas the morning after the
Batchelor's cotillon and all over the
Hopkins campus there was serenity
till two debutantes visited Dr
Mitchell's 9:30 class in economics. It
was such good news that every seat
was occupied.
The bell rang, the noise faded to a
murmur, and then Dr Mitchell spoke:
"I don't know what brought this
on, but I am delighted to have such
responsive talent this morning. We
have been studying the primary
causes of the industrial revolution
and since you have such eagerness to
learn, you shall certainly get the opportunity."
The visiting students held their
breath, then Dr Mitchell continued:
"The inequality of wealth distribution has frequently been condemned. It is estimated that one
family out of every 400 on the average has as much income as the other
399 put together."
"It would cost approximately $13
a week for a family of four to be put
on direct relief. Let us bear this point
in mind, for we will return to it.
"Now, just what did this cotillion
cost?" The Students gave a sigh of
relief. Dr Mitchell got up, prepared
to write on the board. He inquired
how many people attended the dance.
The number given by one of the students in the class, was 1,147 people,
75 debutantes. In round numbers
there were 800 men and 400 women
present. He then proceeded to obtain
a list of the items for this dance, with
estimated cost of each.
In the calculating of the cost of
certain garments which might be
worn more than once, only a part of
the cost was allocated to this dance.
The debutantes were at variance
upon the price of food. The one said
$1.25 a plate while the other maintained $.50. Dr Mitchell looked over
to the one and said:
"If it was just a snack? The young
lady said she had a sandwich."
"I didn't say that" she replied.
Finally the debutantes compromised
and the price was set at $1.00 a plate,
a total of $1200.
They disagreed again about the
price of boxes of flowers. One said
$5 the other $3, whereupon Dr
Mitchell explained the difference was
between the liberal and conservative.
The liquor queStion was reached.
The students agreed that 600 pints
would be a fair figure.
"Oh, no, not that much liquor!"
one of the debutantes answered,
"They had mostly White Rock, carbonated water."

"What

about

the

champagne?"

some one remarked.
"Oh

the

champagne

didn't last

very long" she retorted.
When Dr Mitchell was questioning the girls- about the cost of various pieces of women's clothing and
incidentals used at the dance there
would

infrequently

be

disturbing

murmurs about how low some of the
prices were set. Dr Mitchell invariably had to stop to tell them.
"Now wait a minute, you don't
know anything about women's dresses."
"There are a lot of things which
show up very well but really didn't
cost much." commented a debutante.
"Indeed," Dr Mitchell added, "I've
heard that at some hunting clubs you
could get a good deal of second hand
things: you could get a second hand
saddle, a second hand pair of boots
and even a second hand fox." •
"What about the railroad fare?"
questioned a student. Wouldn't those
people coming from New York have
to pay a fare?
"That is a good point" affirmed Dr
Mitchell, "a lot of these people are
from foreign countries like---Catonsville.
The following list is the approximate value of the terns which were
determined. "It is by no means an
exact list" said Dr Mitchell.
$400 for rental, $1200 food, $1000
orchestra, $50 decorations, $1000
corsages, $24,000 flowers, $100 parties, $600 liquor, $2400 railroad, $600
tax, $3200 dresses, $200 shoes, $160
stockings, $800 undies, $200 wraps,
$700 hairaressers, $125 manicures,
$800 men's suits, $2000 vests, shirts,
ties, etc., $2000 jewelry, $200 men's
coats, hats, $200 women's gloves,
$2500 invitations and cards, $800 tips
and $1500 for hotels. Total—$49,430
or approximately $650 per debutante
was spent.
When we return to the original
statement that $13 would support
a family of four people on relief for
one week, we discover that 50 families
for one week could be supported by
the money spent on each debutante.
Or a relief population (two families
to the house) filling the area between
Charles street to Harford road and
North avenue to 32nd street, could be
supported for one week.
The point of the lecture is whether
it is advantageous to stimulate such
business since many people might
say that the florists and hairdressers
etc., had to be kept alive, while people
in the society are starving for food.
At this point the bell rang ending
this delightful period.

J B Lawrence

in this corner
I write this paragraph on Dec 4;
it may or may not be published before Christmas, regardless of the sympathy and wishes of the editor and,
I am led to believe, a majority of the
N-L board. Not yet this school year
has this column appeared within two
weeks of submission. Twice it has
been mysteriously lost in the N-L
office where the forces of liberalism
make their terrestrial home. Because
of the state of anarchy existing
among the editorial staff, two or
three obstructionist underlings, cringing in fear of an outbreak of independent thought have resorted to
surreptitious sabotage, and even to
oiirright, brazen suppression. They
have created a real need for the
school motto; but campus opinion
cannot be made free, if truth itself
is gagged and fettered. This paper
has ceased to represent a cross-section of campus opinion; instead, a
minority of malcontents has corrupted the ideals of journalism by their
petty totalitarianism.
THREE out of four fighters for
pure principle who sat on the platform at the the-dean-is-unwise-butwe-love-him meeting are members of
the ASU. The demonstration was informed that the speakers represented a certain "Committee of Thirty."
I do not believe that the ASU has a
large enough membership to fill threefourths quota on such a committee,
but it may be assumed that they did
the best they could. Must we accept
such a percentage as representative
of the campus, and if not, where is all
their beloved democracy, whose name
they take in vain? Note that practically all the revolutions in history
were formented by self-seeking minorities who duped the masses with
tempting catchwords of idealism.
Then as now, these self-appointed
popular leaders represented no one
but themselves and their personal interests.
The face of the N-L was badly

blackened by a recent headline therein Hearstly referred to the "Jap
Policy." This is disgraceful and inexcusable. Brevity cannot be used as
an explanation; if such an argument
is admissable, why not go the whole
hog? Will there be headlines of Frogs
Chinks, Wops, Hunks, Boches, or
Limeys?
THE PRESIDE= in his pre-election indorsement of Murphy of Michigan seemed to smear himself with
Chamberlainism. He praised Murphy
for yielding to force and thereby
avoiding violence. In the Flint affair,
Murphy, because of his sympathies
with the aims of the strikers, surrendered to his fear -and refused to
allow his law-enforcement agencies
to function. There is in Michigan,
as in England, a need for courageous
public officials which is greater than
the supply.
FIGHT DISEASE! "World Healthways, Inc" has the plan by which
suffering humanity will be spared the
total economic waste of doctor's bills,
and at the same time can eliminate
from the face of the earth those merchants of death, the medical profession, who collect profits from the sick
and dying, and are doubtless secretly
involved in the spreading of epidemics. Let us liberals rid the world of
these monsters, and their tool and
means of livelihood—disease, which
menace us all; nor does it discriminate in favor of women or babies, but
71aughters without scruple for age or
sex. What is our plan? We will assemble representatives from all over
the country and through them, all
will swear a holy oath that disease
must cease, and that no more of our
hard-earned salaries will be paid to
heartless, undemocratic, greedy science. America needs schools, not hospitals. Too long our hapless land has
yielded power and plunder to the
aristocratic medical clique. Idealism
must rise and conquer; join now!
